results.title: Even cowgirls get the blues
results.creator_credit: Gus Van Sant, Laurie Parker, Fourth Features and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: Even cowgirls get the blues is a comedy directed by Gus Van Sant (My own private Idaho, Psycho, Good Will Hunting, To die for), who also wrote the screenplay, from the Tom Robbins book of the same name. Uma Thurman stars as Sissy Hankshaw, a woman born with enormous thumbs, which leads her to believe that her destiny is to hitchhike around America, looking for some meaning in her life. Sissy is essentially a social outcast in search of a family who will accept her and her oversized thumbs. After spending time in New York as a model, Sissy finds herself at the Rubber Rose Ranch on an assignment, where she meets and falls in love with Bonanza Jellybean (Rain Phoenix). Jellybean is planning to take over the ranch from The Countess (John Hurt) and Miss Adrian (Angie Dickinson). The film is riddled with other subplots involving peyote, whooping cranes and a mountain-man prophet, The Chink (Pat Morita), with whom Sissy forms a relationship. Cast also includes Roseanne Arnold, Buck Henry, Sean Young, Crispin Glover, Keanu Reeves, Heather Graham and a cameo by William Burroughs. Author Tom Robbins provides a voice-over narration, reading prose from his book, “Even cowgirls get the blues”. Soundtrack by K.D. Lang.

results.title: Europa Europa
results.creator_credit: Agnieszka Holland, Arthur Brauner, Filmkunst and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description: A movie that proves that fact is far more bizarre than fiction. Based on the autobiography of Solomon Perel, “Europa Europa” follows the extraordinary adventures of a Jewish boy becomes one of the prize pupils in the Hitler Youth. Young Solomon’s attempts to evade the Nazi slaughter of the Jews is a tragi-comedy of epic porportions. While the war escalates in horror and intensity, Solomon relies on his good looks and sharp wits to survive. From Communist training camp to the elite Nazi school in Berlin, Solomon’s journey takes him across Germany, Poland and Eastern Europe. “Europa Europa” is such an exhilerating movie to watch - fast, colourful, exciting - it is only on reflection that the full resonance of Solomon’s story has its effect. His chameleon changes of self in order to survive undermine both radical and humanist notions of the “hero” and the film asks unsettling and difficult questions about complicity and collaboration in violence. This film is alive: one moment we are laughing out loud at Solomon’s attempts to hide his penis from view (and its telling lack of foreskin) and in the next moment we confront the stark inhuman obscenity of the Warsaw Ghetto. A rivetting, important, complex film.

results.title: Escape from Sobibor
results.creator_credit: Dennis E. Doty, Rule-Starger Productions, Zenith Productions and Jack Gold
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Richard Rashke, and unpublished manuscripts From the ashes of Sobibor” by Thomas Blatt and “Inferno in Sobibor by Stanislaw Szmajzner, this made for television (originally as a miniseries) drama tells the true story of a heroic escape by Jewish prisoners in the Nazi death camp in the forests of Sobibor, a Polish village, in October 1943. During the camp’s operation from May 1942 to October 1943, approximately 250,000 Polish and Russian Jews were exterminated in the five gas chambers - only the skilled survived to work as labourers under the watchful and often brutal Nazi guards. But even those who did survive knew they were on borrowed time. Escape was the only answer. The traumatised prisoners, led by Leon Feldhendler (Alan Arkin) along with the support of the prisoners of war Russian soldiers under the command of Alexander Percherski (Rutger Hauer), hatch a fantastic plan of escape. However, this ambitious plan is not just for a handful of prisoners, it is a chance for all 600 prisoners to make a bid for freedom and survival. This uprising proved to be the largest and most successful of its kind during World War II. For forty years the world was unaware of the events - the Nazis destroyed the camp and all of its records in a cover-up by burning it to the ground. An intense human drama displaying some of the brutality, but also the determination, spirit and courage of those who survived the Holocaust and this most amazing escape. Cast also includes Joanna Pacula, Hartmut Becker, Simon Gregor and Jack Shepherd.

results.title: Eraserhead
results.creator_credit: David Lynch, Lynch/Frost Productions and American Film Institute
results.brief_description: Lynch’s debut film has been re-released with a new print and stereo mix soundtrack. Opinion is divided as to film’s brilliance but over the years it has achieved cult status in it’s genre. Shot in black and white with an incredible soundtrack and tight script, ‘Eraserhead’ is the story of a timid printer Henry Spencer (John Nance) who lives in an apartment building trying to figure out what to do with his horribly mutated son. Lynch described the film as ” a dream of dark and troubling things.”

results.title: Equus
results.creator_credit: Sidney Lumet, Lester Persky, Elliott Kastner, Denis Holt and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Peter Firth plays Alan Strang, a young man working as a stableboy at an upper-class riding school who one night brutally blinds the horses. Richard Burton is psychiatrist Dr. Martin Dysart who is investigating the reasons for the young man’s apparent senseless crime. Based on Peter Shaffer’s acclaimed play, “Equus” is a film that explores and manages to traverse a rich field of themes and concerns: psychoanalysis and mythology; sexuality and repression; class and family; sex and power. The relationship between analyst and patient becomes increasingly complex as the mysteries of the boy’s repressions become unravelled. The men’s exchanges begin to be complicated by the echoes of homoeroticism and the psychological overtones of the Oedipal Complex. Though dominated by the performances of Burton and Firth, “Equus” features an excellent supporting cast including Joan Plowright, Eileen Atkins and Jenny Agutter. Initially dividing critics, “Equus” has become a cult favourite through the years and is acknowledged as one of Lumet’s darker and innovative works.

results.title: Epsilon
results.creator_credit: Film Finance Corporation Australia, Fandango, Rolf De Heer and Domenico Procacci
results.brief_description: This unusual early feature from Rolf de Heer is an intergalactic love-story between a woman from the outer space, who is sent from the planet Epsilon to pass judgment on the shameful way in which humans have mishandled their planet, and an earthbound man. Stunning land/nightscapes (the outback, great cities, and vista’s full of stars) are major characters as the two map the spaces, times and places of the heart. Cast includes Ulli Birve and Syd Brisbane.

results.title: Entr'acte
results.brief_description: A humorous cinematic poem attempting to capture all the images and associations of carnival, which dissolve into each other in the dreams of a young man who has just returned from an evening at the fair. There is no plot, each image suggesting the one to follow. This is one of the most celebrated of French avant-garde films. Made originally for a ballet called “Relache” (i.e. performance suspended) it was thus a joke within a joke - an entr’acte or intermission in a non-existent performance. No spoken word, this film’s story was written by Francis Picabia with music by Erik Satie

results.title: Enter the dragon
results.creator_credit: Robert Clouse, Paul Heller, Fred Weintraub, Concorde Productions and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: One of the biggest martial arts epics ever filmed. Bruce Lee, determined to avenge the murder of his sister, enters the island fortress of crime warlord Han. Lee staged his own fighting sequences in the movie and the sequences are thrilling in their timing and execution. ‘Enter the dragon’ was Lee’s last film and his untimely death at a young age, a few weeks after the film’s completion had made this a landmark film of its genre.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Clouse, Paul Heller, Fred Weintraub, Concorde Productions and Warner Bros Pictures

results.title: Empty Quarter
results.brief_description:
Set in Djibouti, this story is filmed in subjective camera style. An introspective, slightly self-absorbed journalist asks a French woman to share a room with him. He is attracted to her but is not sure how to go about making that point clear. They spend their time in banal conversation. After seeing an Australian movie (‘The man from Snowy River’) they decide to make their way across the desert to Alexandria.

Credits: Producers, Pascale Dauman, Francois Margolin ; director, Raymond Depardon ; writer, Raymond Depardon ; photography, Raymond Depardon.
Cast: Francoise Prenant.

results.title: El Cid
results.creator_credit: Anthony Mann, Samuel Bronston and DEAR Film
results.brief_description: This dazzling big budget spectacle set in twelfth century Spain brings to life the remarkable tale of Rodrigo Diaz de Bivar - El Cid - a man torn between his sense of honour and his undying loyalty to the crown, and the triumphs and tragedies that await him as he strives to unite his countrymen in a battle against the common enemy. Shot entirely on location in Spain, this film is an extravagant tribute to one of history’s greatest military leaders, a man who earned the respect of Christians and Muslims alike with his compassion and courage, and whose legend was further magnified in an epic twelfth century poem, El cantar del mio Cid. Charlton Heston offers his usual charismatic performance in the lead role, while Sophia Loren is luminous and restrained as the tortured heroine, Ximena. Director Anthony Mann, best known for his Westerns and noirs (and for having directed the first hour of the biblical epic Spartacus before personal differences with star Kirk Douglas forced his replacement) recreates the turbulent grandeur of medieval Spain with spectacular results, filling just over three hours of screen time with huge sets, lavish costumes and weaponry, and impressive and realistic battle sequences. El Cid was nominated for three Academy Awards - Art Direction, Best Song and Best Musical Score - and picked up a Golden Globe award in 1962 for producer Samuel Bronston. Stars Raf Vallone as Count Ordonez, Ralph Truman as King Ferdinand, Genevieve Page as Princess Urraca, John Fraser as Prince Alfonso, Gary Raymond as Prince Sancho, and Herbert Lom as Ben Yusef, with a sweeping musical score by Milkos Rosza.

El Cid was nominated for three Academy Awards - Art Direction, Best Song and Best Musical Score - and picked up a Golden Globe award in 1962 for producer Samuel Bronston. Stars Raf Vallone as Count Ordonez, Ralph Truman as King Ferdinand, Genevieve Page as Princess Urraca, John Fraser as Prince Alfonso, Gary Raymond as Prince Sancho, and Herbert Lom as Ben Yusef, with a sweeping musical score by Milkos Rosza.
description_for_label: This dazzling big budget spectacle set in twelfth century Spain brings to life the remarkable tale of Rodrigo Diaz de Bivar - El Cid - a man torn between his sense of honour and his undying loyalty to the crown, and the triumphs and tragedies that await him as he strives to unite his countrymen in a battle against the common enemy. Shot entirely on location in Spain, this film is an extravagant tribute to one of history’s greatest military leaders, a man who earned the respect of Christians and Muslims alike with his compassion and courage, and whose legend was further magnified in an epic twelfth century poem, El cantar del mio Cid. Charlton Heston offers his usual charismatic performance in the lead role, while Sophia Loren is luminous and restrained as the tortured heroine, Ximena. Director Anthony Mann, best known for his Westerns and noirs (and for having directed the first hour of the biblical epic Spartacus before personal differences with star Kirk Douglas forced his replacement) recreates the turbulent grandeur of medieval Spain with spectacular results, filling just over three hours of screen time with huge sets, lavish costumes and weaponry, and impressive and realistic battle sequences. El Cid was nominated for three Academy Awards - Art Direction, Best Song and Best Musical Score - and picked up a Golden Globe award in 1962 for producer Samuel Bronston. Stars Raf Vallone as Count Ordonez, Ralph Truman as King Ferdinand, Genevieve Page as Princess Urraca, John Fraser as Prince Alfonso, Gary Raymond as Prince Sancho, and Herbert Lom as Ben Yusef, with a sweeping musical score by Milkos Rosza.
